dialogues.WILL:
[1]Doubt that the stars are fire, doubt that the sun doth move 
[2]It is all locked safe in here 
[3]As soon as I have found my muse 
[4]She is always Aphrodite. 
[5]Henslowe, you have no soul so how can you understand the emptiness that seeks a soulmate? 
[6]What piece? Richard Crookback? 
[7]Who wrote that? 
[8]Half what you owed me. I am still due for One Gentleman of Verona. 
[9]Mr. Henslowe, will you lend me fifty pounds? 
[10]Burbage offers me a partnership in the Chamberlain's Men. For fifty pounds my hired player days are over. 
[11]No, then. 
[12]To my weekly confession. 
[13]Words, words, wordsonce, I had the giftI could make love out of words as a potter makes cups out of clay love that overthrows empires, love that binds two hearts together come hellfire and brimstonesfor sixpence a line, I could cause a riot in a nunnerybut now 
[14]Aye, now and again, but what of it? I have lost my gift. 
[15]I have lost my gift. It's as if my quill is broken. As if the organ of the imagination has dried up. As if the proud tower of my genius has collapsed. 
[16]Nothing comes. 
[17]It is like trying to a pick a lock with a wet herring. 
[18]A goodly length in times past, but lately 
[19]I was a lad of eighteen. Anne Hathaway was a woman, half as old again. 
[20]She had a cottage. One day, she was three months gone with child, so 
[21]On my mother's side the Ardens 
[22]Four years and a hundred miles away in Stratford. A cold bed too, since the twins were born. Banishment was a blessing. 
[23]yet cannot love nor write it. 
[24]Will it restore my gift? 
[25]To the Palace at Whitehall. 
[26]Prithee, Mr. Kempe, break a leg. You too, good Crab. 
[27]No, they would laugh at Seneca if you played it. 
[28]I am still owed money for this play, Burbage. 
[29]When I have fifty pounds. 
[30]A comedy. All but done, a pirate comedy, wonderful. 
[31]Romeo. Wit, swordsman, lover. 
[32]Romeo 
[33]It's for Henslowe. He paid me. 
[34]Ten pounds. 
[35]I swear it. He wants Romeo for Ned and the Admiral's Men. 
[36]Done. 
[37]I have lost my gift. 
[38]Are you to be my muse, ROSALINE? 
[39]You see? The consumptives plot against me. "Will Shakespeare has a play, let us go and cough through it." 
[40]I feel a scene coming on. 
[41]Romeo and Rosaline. Scene One! God, I'm good! 
[42]Richard! 
[43]Burbage? 
[44]Mr. Tilney 
[45]So this is the favour you find in the Chamberlain's Men. 
[46]I would have made you immortal. Tell Burbage he has lost a new play by Will Shakespeare. 
[47]You have opened the playhouses? 
[48]But the plague 
[49]Yes. Nearly. It's all locked safe in here. We need Ralph for the Pirate King. Good morning, Master Nol. You will have a nice little part. 
[50]Give me to drink mandragora. 
[51]Kit 
[52]Wonderful, wonderful. 
[53]I have. And chinks to show for it. 
[54]I insist--and a beaker for Mr. Marlowe. The BARMAN does the business. 
[55]I hear you have a new play for the Curtain. 
[56]I love your early work. "Was this the face that launched a thousand ships and burnt the topless towers of Ilium?" 
[57]Good title. 
[58]Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter. Yes, I know. 
[59]Well, there's a pirate In truth, I have not written a word. 
[60]Yes, that's good. Until he meets 
[61]Do you think? 
[62]The daughter of his enemy. 
[63]Mercutiogood name. 
[64]I'm coming. 
[65]Good luck with yours, Kit. 
[66]This is a different one. 
[67]I did not. 
[68]Tomorrow 
[69]please God. 
[70]Your name? 
[71]Take off your hat. 
[72]Where did you learn how to do that? 
[73]Wait there. 
[74]Let me see you. Take off your hat. 
[75]Where's the boy? 
[76]Follow that boat! 
[77]Yes. 
[78]Really? 
[79]Do you know that house? 
[80]The actor 
[81]William Shakespeare, actor, poet, and playwright of the Rose. 
[82]I will wait. 
[83]Master Plum! What business here? 
[84]I seek Master Thomas Kent. 
[85]By all the stars in heaven, who is she? 
[86]anaesthetic and not noticing the danger 
[87]How do I offend, my lord? 
[88]Christopher Marlowe at your service. 
[89]My lady! 
[90]Will Shakespeare! 
[91]The same, alas. 
[92]A lowly player. 
[93]Oh--I am him too! 
[94]Oh, I am fortune's fool, I will be punished for this! 
[95]Oh my lady, my love! 
[96]You can bring them with a word. 
[97]We are at least six men short, and those we have will be overparted, ranters and stutterers who should be sent back to the stews. My Romeo has let me down. I see disaster. 
[98]Who are you, master? 
[99]I'll be damned if you are! 
[100]Gentlemen! Thank you! You are welcome. 
[101]We are about to embark on a great voyage. 
[102]You want to know what parts you are to receive. All will be settled as we go 
[103]We are in desperate want of a Mercutio, Ned, a young nobleman of Verona 
[104]Mercutio 
[105]Mr. Pope! Mr. Phillips! Welcome, George Bryan! James Armitage! Sam! My pretty one! Are you ready to fall in love again? 
[106]But your voice Have they dropped? 
[107]Master Henslowe, you have your actors. 
[108]Yes, I saw it. 
[109]Better fortune, boy. 
[110]You admire it? 
[111]Oh. What is your name? 
[112]I have to get back. 
[113]Cut round him for now. 
[114]Romeo. 
[115]What? 
[116]Good 
[117]No, no, noDon't spend it all at once! 
[118]Do you understand me? 
[119]He is speaking about a baggage we never even meet! What will be left in your purse when he meets his Juliet? 
[120]God's teeth, am I to suffer this constant stream of interruption?! What will you do in Act Two when he meets the love of his life? 
[121]Of course you have not! I have not written it! 
[122]Go once more! 
[123]Locked safe in here. I leave the scene in your safe keeping, Ned, I have a sonnet to write. 
[124]You did not like the speech? 
[125]There you have his duel, a skirmish of words and swords such as I never wrote, nor anyone. He dies with such passion and poetry as your ever heard: "a plague on both your houses!" 
[126]Did you give her my letter? 
[127]Oh, Thomas! She has cut my strings! I am unmanned, unmended, and unmade, like a puppet in a box. 
[128]Row your boat. 
[129]She tells me to keep away. She is to marry Lord Wessex. What should I do? 
[130]And break her heart and mine? 
[131]She loves me, Thomas! 
[132]No. And yet she does where the ink has run with tears. Was she weeping when she gave you this? 
[133]Your aunt? 
[134]Like a sickness and its cure together. 
[135]Oh, if I could write the beauty of her eyes! I was born to look in them and know myself. 
[136]Oh, Thomas, her lips! The early morning rose would wither on the branch, if it could feel envy! 
[137]Deeper. Softer. None of your twittering larks! I would banish nightingales from her garden before they interrupt her song. 
[138]Constantly. Without doubt. And plays the lute, she has a natural ear. And her bosom--did I mention her bosom? 
[139]Oh Thomas, a pair of pippins! As round and rare as golden apples! 
[140]Yes, by God! Love knows nothing of rank or riverbank! It will spark between a queen and the poor vagabond who plays the king, and their love should be minded by each, for love denied blights the soul we owe to God! So tell my lady, William Shakespeare waits for her in the garden! 
[141]For one kiss, I would defy a thousand Wessexes! 
[142]Lady? 
[143]Can you love a fool? 
[144]Wait! You are still a maid and perhaps as mistook in me as I was mistook in Thomas Kent. 
[145]I am. 
[146]It is strange to me, too. 
[147]There is. 
[148]Oh 
[149]Well perhaps better than my first. 
[150]I must. Look-- how pale the window. 
[151]No, the morning rooster woke me. 
[152]Oh, let Henslowe wait. 
[153]Let him be damned for his pages! 
[154]There is time. It is still dark. 
[155]It was the owl. Believe me, love, it was the owl. 
[156]Yesyesernot quite rightit is more let me "Then have my lips the sin that they have took." 
[157]Yes, yescontinue. Now the Nurse. Where is Ralph? 
[158]I must. I must 
[159]Yes, some of it is speakable. 
[160]"Oh Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo? Deny thy father and refuse thy name." 
[161]"What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night So stumblest on my counsel?" 
[162]"The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art, If any of my kinsmen find thee here. If they do see thee, they will murder thee." 
[163]"Good night, good night. As sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast. O wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?" 
[164]Oh, but it is mine too! 
[165]"My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep: 
[166]"Stay but a little, I will come again." 
[167]How is it? 
[168]NedI knowI know 
[169]Oh 
[170]Ah 
[171]Thank you, Ned. 
[172]You are a gentleman. 
[173]Sundayit is Sunday. 
[174]I found something in my sleep. The Friar who married them will take up their destinies. 
[175]In heaven, perhaps. It is not a comedy I am writing now. A broad river divides my lovers--family, duty, fate--as unchangeable as nature. 
[176]You cannot! Not for the Queen herself! 
[177]To be the wife of a poor player?--can I wish that for Lady Viola, except in my dreams? And yet I would, if I were free to follow my desire in the harsh light of day. 
[178]Then I will go with you. 
[179]I know how to fight! 
[180]Here we come at last, my lord! 
[181]Her chaperone. My lady's country cousin. My, but you be a handsome gallant, just as she said! You may call me Miss Wilhelmina! 
[182]Oh, my lord, you will not shake me off, she never needed me more, I sear by your breeches! 
[183]A man, my lord? 
[184]A theatre poet? 
[185]Marlowe? Oh yes, he is the one, lovely waistcoat, shame about the poetry. 
[186]Fifty pounds! 
[187]What is this rabble?! 
[188]A literary feud. Quite normal. 
[189]Stay hid! 
[190]I dreamed last night of a shipwreck. You were cast ashore in a far country. 
[191]Is this a tavern? 
[192]It is also a tavern. 
[193]It is, Thomas, but of good reputation. Come, there is no harm in a drink. 
[194]Mr. Fennyman, because you love the theatre you must have a part in my play. I am writing an Apothecary, a small but vital role. 
[195]By God, I wish I knew. 
[196]Ohwhat have I done? 
[197]It was I who killed him! God forgive me, God forgive me! 
[198]It is worse. I have killed a man. 
[199]Marlowe's touch was in my Titus Andronicus and my Henry VI was a house built on his foundations. 
[200]He was not dead before. I would exchange all my plays to come for all of his that will never come. 
[201]My love is no lie. I have a wife, yes, and I cannot marry the daughter of Sir Robert de Lesseps. It needed no wife come from Stratford to tell you that. And yet you let me come to your bed. 
[202]I was the more deceived. 
[203]Now? 
[204]Oh, my love You ran from me before. 
[205]You cannot marry Wessex! 
[206]Nono. 
[207]For killing Juliet's kinsman Tybalt, the one who killed Romeo's friend Mercutio, Romeo is banished 
[208]but the Friar who married Romeo and Juliet 
[209]You, Edward. The Friar who married them gives Juliet a potion to drink. It is a secret potion. It makes her seeming dead. She is placed in the tomb of the Capulets. She will awake to life and love when Romeo comes to her side again. 
[210]I have not said all. By malign fate, the message goes astray which would tell Romeo of the Friar's plan. He hears only that Juliet is dead. And thus he goes to the Apothecary. 
[211]And buys a deadly poison. He enters the tomb to say farewell to Juliet who lies there cold as death. He drinks the poison. He dies by her side. And then she wakes and sees him dead. 
[212]And so Juliet takes his dagger and kills herself. 
[213]The play. All written out for you. I had the clerk at Bridewell do it, he has a good fist for lettering. 
[214]There's a new scene 
[215]"Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet near day> It was the nightingale and not the lark That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear. Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate tree. Believe me, love, it was the nightingale." 
[216]"Yon light is not daylight, I know it, I. It is some meteor that the sun exhales To be to thee this night a torchbearer" 
[217]"thou need'st not to be gone." 
[218]You are on my ground. 
[219]I am more than enough. 
[220]Absent friends! This is the murderer of Kit Marlowe! 
[221]Oh God, I am free of it! 
[222]We are lost. 
[223]How will it? 
[224]Wonderful! 
[225]Luck be with you, Sam. Sam? 
[226]Sam! Do me a speech, do me a line. 
[227]What do we do now? 
[228]Go on. 
[229]How will it? 
[230]I am fortune's fool. 
[231]You are married? 
[232]If you be married, my gave is like to be my wedding bed. The implication of her silence fills the air. WILL does not move. 
[233]My Lady Wessex? 
[234]I am done with theatre. The playhouse is for dreamers. Look where the dream has brought us. 
[235]I have hurt you and I am sorry for it. 
[236]A comedy! What will my hero be but the saddest wretch in the kingdom, sick with love? 
[237]Sold in marriage and half way to America. 
[238]Orsinogood name 
[239]and thus unable to declare her love 
[240]How does it? 
[241]You will never age for me, nor fade, nor die. 
[242]Good bye, my love, a thousand times good bye. 
[243]My story starts at seaa perilous voyage to an unknown landa shipwreck 
[244]the wild waters roar and heavethe brave vessel is dashed all to pieces, and all the helpless souls within her drowned 
[245]all save one  a lady 
[246]whose soul is greater than the ocean  and her spirit stronger than the sea's embrace  not for her watery end, but a new life beginning on a stranger shore 
[247]It will be a love story  for she will be my heroine for all time 
[248]and her name will be  Viola.
dialogues.VIOLA:
[1]Did you like Proteus or Valentine best? Proteus for speaking, Valentine for looks. 
[2]But Silvia I did not care for much. His fingers were red from fighting and he spoke like a schoolboy at lessons. Stage love will never be true love while the law of the land has our heroines played by pipsqueak boys in petticoats! Oh, when can we see another? 
[3]But at the playhouse. Nurse? 
[4]I am not so well-born. 
[5]All the men at court are without poetry. If they look at me they see my father's fortune. I will have poetry in my life. And adventure. And love. Love above all. 
[6]No . . . not the artful postures of love, but love that over- throws life. Unbiddable, ungovernable, like a riot in the heart, and nothing to be done, come ruin or rapture. Love like there has never been in a play. I will have love or I will end my days as a . . . 
[7]But I would be Valentine and Silvia too. Good Nurse, God save you and good night. I would stay asleep my whole life if I could dream myself into a company of players. 
[8]God save you, mother. Ho water, nurse. 
[9]He sees himself in me! Romeo Montague, a young man of Verona. 
[10]A comedy of quarreling families reconciled in the discovery of Romeo to be the very same Capulet cousin stolen from the cradle and fostered to manhood by his Montague mother that was robbed of her own child by the Pirate King! 
[11]From tomorrow, away in the country for three weeks! Is Master Shakespeare not handsome? 
[12]Oh, Nurse! He would give Thomas Kent the life of Viola De Lesseps's dreaming. 
[13]You will not tell. As you love me and as I love you, you will bind my breast and buy me a boy's wig! 
[14]Master Shakespeare 
[15]My lord. 
[16]So my lord? I speak with him every day. 
[17]Good sir ? 
[18]I heard you are a poet. 
[19]But a poet of no words? 
[20]Romeo, Romeo . . . a young man of Verona. A comedy. By William Shakespeare. 
[21]Who is there? 
[22]Anon, good nurse. Anon. Master Shakespeare?! 
[23]Oh but why "alas?" 
[24]Alas indeed, for I thought you the highest poet of my esteem and a writer of plays that capture my heart. 
[25]Anon, anon! I will come again. 
[26]If they find you here they will kill you. 
[27]Oh, not for the world! 
[28]Anon, nurse! 
[29]Lord Wessex. You have been waiting. 
[30]You flatter, my lord. 
[31]Do you intend to marry, my lord? 
[32]I do not love you, my lord. 
[33]Virginia?! 
[34]But why me? 
[35]The Queen has consented? 
[36]I will do my duty, my lord. 
[37]Oh, Will! 
[38]Can you love a player? 
[39]Answer me only this: are you the author of the plays of William Shakespeare? 
[40]Then kiss me again for I am not mistook. 
[41]I do not know how to undress a man. 
[42]I would not have thought it. There is something better than a play. 
[43]Even your play. 
[44]And that was only my first try. 
[45]Will 
[46]You would not leave me? 
[47]Moonlight! 
[48]It was the owl--come to bed 
[49]Mr. Henslowe? 
[50]Oh--no, no! 
[51]It is broad day! The rooster tells us so! 
[52]You would leave us players without a scene to read today?! 
[53]It is a new world! 
[54]Oh let it be night! 
[55]Oh, do not go 
[56]"But soft, what light through yonder window breaks? It is the east and Juliet is the sun!" 
[57]"Arise fair sun and kill the envious moon Who is already sick and pale with grief That thou her maid art far more fair than she" 
[58]Oh, Will! 
[59]"It is my lady, O it is my love! O that she knew she were!" 
[60]That's my line! 
[61]Anon, good Nurse 
[62]"I am feared, 
[63]Oh, but it will end well for love? 
[64]Yes, this is not life, Will. This is a stolen season. 
[65]Sunday! Greenwich! 
[66]What will you have me do? Marry you instead? 
[67]You follow your desire freely enough in the night. So, if that is all, to Greenwich I go. 
[68]You cannot, Wessex will kill you 
[69]Stage fighting! Oh, Will! As Thomas Kent my heart belongs to you but as Viola the river divides us, and I will marry Wessex a week from Saturday. 
[70]Good morning, my lord! 
[71]Your Majesty. 
[72]Your Majesty. 
[73]Your Majesty 
[74]I love theatre. To have stories acted for me by a company of fellows is indeed 
[75]And I love poetry above all. 
[76]Oh, but they can! 
[77]I meanYour Majesty, they do not, they have not, but I believe there is one who can 
[78]Will! What--? 
[79]It is not my riding day, my lord. 
[80]I am going to church. 
[81]It is to be expected on a Sunday. 
[82]Mourning? Who is dead, my lord? 
[83]He is dead? 
[84]Will! 
[85]Oh, my love, I thought you were dead! 
[86]You never spoke so well of him. 
[87]You lie. 
[88]You lie in your meadow as you lied in my bed. 
[89]Calf love. I loved the writer, and gave up the prize for a sonnet. 
[90]I love you, Will, beyond poetry. 
[91]You were not dead before. When I thought you dead, I did not care about all the plays that will never come, only that I would never see your face. I saw our end, and it will come. 
[92]If not Wessex the Queen will know the cause and there will be no more Will Shakespeare. 
[93]But I will go to Wessex as a widow from these vows, as solemn as they are unsanctified. 
[94]Will you read it for me? 
[95]"It was the lark, the herald of the morn, No nightingale. Look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east. Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops. I must be gone and live, or stay and die." 
[96]"I have more care to stay than will to go. Come death, and welcome. Juliet wills it so. How is't my soul? Let's talk. It is not day." 
[97]Nobody knew! 
[98]I am so sorry, Mr. Henslowe. I wanted to be an actor. I am sorry, Will. 
[99]Thank you. 
[100]Good morning, my lord. I see you are open for business so let's to church. 
[101]No Juliet?! 
[102]What happened to Sam? 
[103]Thomas Kent! 
[104]Every word. 
[105]A hired player no longer. Fifty pounds, Will, for the poet of true love. 
[106]It was we ourselves did that. And for my life to come I would not have it otherwise. 
[107]If my hurt is to be that you will write no more, then I shall be the sorrier. 
[108]The Queen commands a comedy, Will for Twelfth Night. 
[109]An excellent beginning Let him bea duke. And your heroine? 
[110]At sea, then--a voyage to a new world?she lands upon a vast and empty shore. She is brought to the dukeOrsino. 
[111]But fearful of her virtue, she comes to him dressed as a boy 
[112]But all ends well. 
[113]I don't know. It's a mystery 
[114]Nor you for me. 
[115]Write me well.
dialogues.HENSLOWE:
[1]Aaagh! I can pay you! 
[2]Two weeks, three at the most, Aaaagh! For pity's sake. 
[3]I have a wonderful new play! 
[4]It's a comedy. 
[5]A new comedy. By Will Shakespeare! 
[6]And a share. We will be partners, Mr. Fennyman! 
[7]It's a crowd-tickler--mistaken identities, a shipwreck, a pirate king, a bit with a dog, and love triumphant. 
[8]This time it is by Shakespeare. 
[9]Romeo and Ethel the Pirate's Daughter. 
[10]But I have to pay the actors and the authors. 
[11]There's never any 
[12]Mr. Fennyman, I think you may have hit on something. 
[13]Without doubt he is completing it at this very moment. 
[14]Will! Where is my play? Tell me you have it nearly done! Tell me you have it started. You have begun? 
[15]No, no, we haven't the time. Talk prose. Where is my play? 
[16]God be praised! Locked? 
[17]Who is she this time?! 
[18]Aphrodite Baggot who does it behind the Dog and Trumpet? 
[19]Well, I am a dead man and buggered to boot. My theatre is close by the plague these twelve weeks, my company is playing the inn-yards of England, while Burbage and the Chamberlain's Men are invited to court and receive ten pounds to play your piece, written for my theatre, by my writer, at my risk when you were green and grateful - 
[20]No--it's comedy they want, Will! Comedy! Like Romeo and Ethel? 
[21]Nobody! You are writing it for me! I gave you three pounds a month since. 
[22]. . . Will! What is money to you and me? I, your patron, you my wordwright! When the plague lifts Burbage will have a new Christopher Marlowe for the Curtain and I have nothing for the Rose. 
[23]Fifty pounds? What for? 
[24]Cut out my heart! Throw my liver to the dogs! 
[25]Where are you going? 
[26]Now where? Will? 
[27]Burbage, I will see you hanged for a pickpocket. 
[28]And what favour does Mr. Tilney receive from you? 
[29]Is it about a pirate's daughter? 
[30]You see? Comedy. 
[31]Love and a bit with a dog, that's what they like. 
[32]There's a lady knows your play by heart. 
[33]What have I done, Mr. Fennyman? 
[34]Oh, that. 
[35]Mr. Fennyman, let me explain about the theatre business. The natural condition is one of insurmountable obstacles on the road to imminent disaster. Believe me, to be close by the plague is a bagatelle in the ups and downs of owning a theatre. 
[36]Nothing. Strangely enough , it all turns out well. 
[37]I don't know. It's a mystery. 
[38]If you wouldn't mind 
[39]Oh, it's coming, it's coming. 
[40]Will! The theatres are 
[41]Rosaline? You mean Ethel. 
[42]Yes, I heard. The theatres are open. But where is my playwright? 
[43]Chalk it up, Nol. I'm hungry, too. 
[44]Will! Have you finished? 
[45]Ned Alleyn and the Admiral's Men are out on tour. I need actors. Those here who are unknown will have a chance to be known. 
[46]It won't cost you a penny! Auditions in half-an-hour! 
[47]Ralph Bashford! I'd have a part for you but, alas, I hear you are a drunkard's drunkard. 
[48]Thank you. 
[49]How refreshing. 
[50]Thank you! 
[51]Very good, Mr. Wabash. Excellent. Report to the property master. 
[52]My tailor. Wants to be an actor. I have a few debts here and there. Well, that seems to be everybody. Did you see a Romeo? 
[53]Well, I to my work, you to yours. When can I see pages? 
[54]It starts well, and then it's all long- faced about some Rosaline. Where's the comedy, Will. Where's the dog? Do you think it is funny? 
[55]We are at least four acts short, Will, if you are looking for disaster. 
[56]Very well. 
[57]Yes, but very well. 
[58]Nobody. The author. 
[59]It is customary to make a little speech on the first day. It does no harm and authors like it. 
[60]Is it? 
[61]What? Who? 
[62]The one who came with your letter? 
[63]Juliet? You mean Ethel. 
[64]A sonnet? You mean a play. 
[65]You mean, no dog of any kind? 
[66]That must be when he goes on the voyage and gets shipwrecked on the island of the Pirate King. 
[67]Not with my props! 
[68]We need that for the balcony scene! 
[69]My poor Rose! 
[70]I want no more trouble, Mr. Fennyman. As I explained to you, the theatre business 
[71]The Apothecary? Will, what is the story? Where is the shipwreck? How does the comedy end? 
[72]By God, Will, if you do not, who does? Let us have pirates, clowns, and a happy ending, or we will send you back to Stratford to your wife! 
[73]Well, that will have them rolling in the aisles. 
[74]The bill! Oh, vanity, vanity! 
[75]Mr. Tilney, what is this? 
[76]What?! 
[77]Why so? 
[78]He's a woman! 
[79]Ned, I swear I knew nothing of this! 
[80]It is over. 
[81]Will! 
[82]We'll be needing a Romeo 
[83]No, it will turn out well. 
[84]I don't know, it's a mystery. 
[85]Another little problem. 
[86]The show must  you know 
[87]Juliet does not come on for twenty pages. It will be all right. 
[88]I don't know. It's a mystery. 
[89]Can we talk? 
[90]We have no Juliet! 
[91]it will be all right, madam. 
[92]Who are you? 
[93]Do you know it? 
[94]See you in jail.
dialogues.WESSEX:
[1]My plantations in Virginia are not mortgaged for a nutmeg. I have an ancient name that will bring you preferment when your grandson is a Wessex. Is she fertile? 
[2]Is she obedient? 
[3]I like her. 
[4]My lady Viola. 
[5]I have spoken with your father. 
[6]"Poet?" 
[7]By coveting my property. I cannot shed blood in her house but I will cut your throat anon. You have a name? 
[8]Two hours at prayer! 
[9]Piety is for Sunday! And two hours at prayer is not piety, it is self- importance! 
[10]It would be better that you tell her to get off her knees and show some civility to her six-day lord and master. 
[11]My lady VIOLA. 
[12]I am aware of it, but it is beauty's privilege. 
[13]No. I have spoken to the Queen. Her majesty's consent is requisite when a Wessex takes a wife, and once gained, her consent is her command. 
[14]Your father should keep you better informed. He has bought me for you. He returns from his estates to see us married two weeks from Saturday. You are allowed to show your pleasure. 
[15]How your mind hops about! Your father was a shopkeeper, your children will bear arms, and I will recover my fortune. That is the only matter under discussion today. You will like Virginia. 
[16]Why, yes! My fortune lies in my plantations. The tobacco weed. I need four thousand pounds to fit out a ship and put my investments to work--I fancy tobacco has a future. We will not stay there long, three or four years . . . 
[17]It was your eyes. No, your lips. 
[18]Will you defy your father and your Queen? 
[19]She wants to inspect you. At Greenwich, come Sunday. Be submissive, modest, grateful and brief. 
[20]Not ready? Where is she? 
[21]Will you ask Her Majesty to be patient?! 
[22]Now, pay attention, Nursy. The Queen, Gloriana Regina, God's Chosen Vessel, the Radiant One, who shines her light on us, is at Greenwich today, and prepared, during the evening's festivities, to bestow her gracious favour on my choice of wife--and if we're late for lunch, the old boot will not forgive. So you get you to my lady's chamber and produce her with or without her undergarments. 
[23]By heaven, I will drag her down, by the Queen's command 
[24]Ah! My lady! The tide waits for no man, but I swear it would wait for you! 
[25]Are you bringing your laundry woman? 
[26]On a more fortuitous occasion, perhaps 
[27]Now? 
[28]The Queen asks for you. Answer well. 
[29]Is there a man? 
[30]There was a man, poet--a theatre poet, I heard--does he come to the house? 
[31]An insolent penny-a-page rogue, Marlowe, he said, Christopher Marlowe--has he been to the house? 
[32]That dog! 
[33]Lady Viola isyoung in the world. Your Majesty is wise in it. Nature and truth are the very enemies of playacting. I'll wager my fortune. 
[34]Marlowe! 
[35]You look sad, my lady! Let me take you riding. 
[36]Bless me, I thought it was a horse. 
[37]I understand of course. It is to be expected. 
[38]And on a day of mourning. I never met the fellow but once at your house. 
[39]Oh!--dear God, I did not think it would be me to tell you. A great loss to playwriting, and to dancing. 
[40]Killed last night, in a tavern! Come, then, we'll say a prayer for his soul 
[41]Oh, spare me, dear ghost, spare me for the love of Christ! 
[42]Spare me! 
[43]Shakespeare! 
[44]You upstart inky pup! Now I will show you your place, which is in hell! 
[45]By God, I'll fight the lot of you 
[46]I rejoiced at his death because I thought it was yours. That is all I know of Marlowe. 
[47]Close it! 
[48]Close it! Take it down stone by stone! I want it ploughed into the ground, and sown with quick lime! 
[49]My ship is moored at Bankside, bound for Virginia on the afternoon tide--please do not weep, Lady De Lesseps, you are gaining a colony. 
[50]Would you oblige me with fifty or so in gold?--just to settle my accounts at the dockside? 
[51]Ah!--Look, she comes! 
[52]I will. 
[53]Thank you. Let go, there's a good nurse. 
[54]The tide will not wait. Farewell! 
[55]Your Majesty 
[56]Your Majesty! 
[57]Indeed I am a bride short. How is this to end? 
[58]Fifty shillings. Pounds.
dialogues.FENNYMAN:
[1]What am I, Mr. Lambert? 
[2]How badly bitten, Mr. Frees? 
[3]When? 
[4]Take his feet out. Where will you get 
[5]including interest in three weeks? 
[6]Put his feet in. 
[7]Cut his nose off. 
[8]And his ears. 
[9]Partners! 
[10]What's the title? 
[11]Good title. 
[12]A play takes time. Find actors rehearsalslet's say open in three weeks. That's--what--five hundred groundlings at tuppence each, in addition four hundred groundlings tuppence each, in addition four hundred backsides at three pence--a penny extra for a cushion, call it two hundred cushions, say two performance for safety how much is that Mr. Frees? 
[13]Correct! 
[14]A share of the profits. 
[15]Of course not! 
[16]Sign here. 
[17]Romeo and Ethel The Pirate's DaughterAlmost finished? 
[18]This time we take your boots off! 
[19]The theatres are all closed by the plague! 
[20]by order of the Master of the Revels! 
[21]So what do we do? 
[22]How? 
[23]Yes I heard. 
[24]Where is the play? 
[25]Is it going well? 
[26]But nothing is happening. 
[27]Who is that? 
[28]Who is this? 
[29]A moment, sir! 
[30]I am the money! 
[31]Thank you, sir. 
[32]I saw his Tamburlaine, you know. Wonderful. 
[33]Of course, it was mighty writing. There is no one like Marlowe 
[34]Cease your prattling! Get out! A thousand apologies! 
[35]Wonderful, wonderful! And a dog! 
[36]My investment! LAMBERT!!! 
[37]
[38]Henslowe, you pound of tripe, in my business I would be out of business if I had your courage, so don't tell me about business 
[39]A famous victory! Kegs and legs. Open and on the house! Oh what happy hour! 
[40]You are welcome to my best house! Here's to the Admiral's Men! 
[41]Master Kent! You have not dipped your wick? 
[42]By heaven, I thank you! I will be your Apothecary! 
[43]I am to be in your play. 
[44]Mr. Shakespeare has given me the part of the Apothecary! 
[45]That's me. 
[46]Sad and wonderful! I have a blue velvet cap which will do well, I have seen apothecary with a cap just so. 
[47]"Such mortal drugs I have but Mantua's law Is death to any he that utters them." Then him. Then me. 
[48]"Such mortal drugs I have" What is it? What is it? 
[49]Everything all right? 
[50]I would have been goodI would have been great. 
[51]Lambert! 
[52]Kill him! 
[53]Is this all right? 
[54]"Such mortal drugs I have but Mantua's Law Is death to any he that utters them." Then him. Then me. 
[55]I was good. I was great.
dialogues.BURBAGE:
[1]My sleeve wants for a button, Mistress Rosaline, where were my seamstress's eyes? 
[2]There is no dog in the first scene, Will Kempe, thank you. How goes it Will? 
[3]Not from me. I only stole it. When are you coming over to the Chamberlain's Men? 
[4]Are you writing? 
[5]What is the chief part? 
[6]The title? 
[7]I will play him. Bring it tomorrow. 
[8]How much? 
[9]You're a liar. 
[10]Ned is wrong for it. 
[11]Here is two sovereigns--I'll give you two more when you show me the pages. 
[12]The Queen has commanded, she loves a comedy and the Master of the Revels favours us. 
[13]Ask him. 
[14]Will! 
[15]And where are my pages . . . 
[16]What do you want, Kit? 
[17]You have the last act? 
[18]Tomorrow. 
[19]Wait! Will you desist! 
[20]What is money to me like us? Besides, if I need a play, I have another waiting, a comedy by Shakespeare. 
[21]Never! 
[22]I gave Shakespeare two sovereigns for Romeo! 
[23]Treachery! 
[24]Traitor and thief! 
[25]Where is that thieving hack who can't keep his pen in his own ink pot!? 
[26]That can wait. The Master of the Revels despises us for vagrants, tinkers, and peddlers of bombast. But my father, James Burbage, had the first licence to make a company of players from Her Majesty, and he drew from poets the literature of the age. Their fame will be our fame. So let them all know, we are men of parts. We are a brotherhood, and we will be a profession. Will Shakespeare has a play. I have a theatre. The Curtain is yours. 
[27]No Juliet?! 
[28]We will all be put in the clink. 
[29]Arrest who, Mr. Tilney? 
[30]Contempt? You closed the Rose--I have not opened it.
dialogues.ALLEYN:
[1]Huzzah! The Admiral's Men are returned to the house! 
[2]Silence, you god! I am Hieronimo! I am Tamburlaine! I am Faustus! I am Barrabas, the Jew of Malta--of yes, Master Will, and I am Henry VI. What is the play, and what is my part? 
[3]Who are you? 
[4]Then you may remain so long as you remain silent. Pay attention and you will see how genius creates a legend. 
[5]And the title of this piece? 
[6]I will play him! 
[7]WillWhere is Mercutio? 
[8]Gentlemen upstage, ladies downstage! 
[9]Gentlemen upstage! Ladies downstage! Are you a lady, Mr. Kent? 
[10]The speech is excellent. "Oh, then I see Queen Mab hath been with you!" Excellent and a good length. But then he disappears for the length of a bible. 
[11]He dies? 
[12]Suffering cats! 
[13]Well! It was lucky you were here! Why do not I write the rest of your play while you 
[14]Terrible! 
[15]It's good. 
[16]The title won't do. 
[17]Romeo and Juliet--just a suggestion. 
[18]And you are a Warwickshire shit-house. 
[19]Are you going to do it like that? And before the humbled actor can reply NED continues. 
[20]And but one word with one of us? Couple it with something, make it a word and a blow. 
[21]He was the first man among us. A great light has gone out. 
[22]Yes--it will serve. But there's a scene missing between marriage and death. 
[23]Will 
[24]It's true, Will--it was a tavern brawlMarlowe attacked, and got his own knife in the eye. A quarrel about the bill 
[25]Not the billing, the bill! 
[26]Well, Burbage--you never did know when your scene was over. 
[27]What?! A woman?! You mean that goat?!
dialogues.NURSE:
[1]I liked the dog, for laughs. 
[2]When the Queen commands it. 
[3]Be still. 
[4]Playhouses are not for well-born ladies. 
[5]Well-monied is the same as well-born and well-married is more so. Lord Wessex was looking at you tonight. 
[6]Like Valentine and Silvia? 
[7]As a nurse. 
[8]Clean your teeth while you dream, then. 
[9]Now spit 
[10]Who asks for him? 
[11]Master Kent ismy nephew. 
[12]Much god may it do you. 
[13]Verona again. 
[14]Your mother, and your father 
[15]He looks well enough for a mountebank. 
[16]My lady, this play will end badly. I will tell. 
[17]Lady Viola is pious, my lord. 
[18]It would be better that you return tomorrow, my lord. 
[19]Go to, go to. 
[20]My lady, the house is stirring, it is a new day. 
[21]Be patient, my lord, she is dressing. 
[22]My ladymy ladynow is the time to show your breeding. 
[23]My lord! 
[24]Be good to her, my lord! 
[25]God bless you! 
[26]Dead!
dialogues.VIOLA AS THOMAS:
[1]Thomas Kent. I would like to do a speech by a writer who commands the heart of every player. 
[2]"What light is light, if Silvia be not seen, What joy is joy, if Silvia be not by? Unless it be to think that she is by And feed upon the shadow of perfection. 
[3]" except I be by Silvia in the night, There is no music in the nightingale. Unless I look on Silvia in the day, There is no day for me to look upon." 
[4]My hat? 
[5]
[6]Are you Mr. Shakespeare? 
[7]Yes, sir. 
[8]No, sir. 
[9]I am very sorry, sir, I have not seen Act Two. 
[10]And this for you. 
[11]If you love her, you must do what she asks. 
[12]It is only ours you can know. 
[13]Does she say so? 
[14]I  Her letter came to me by the nurse. 
[15]Yes, my aunt. But perhaps she wept a little. Tell me how you love her, Will. 
[16]Yes, like rain and sun, like cold and heat. Is your lady beautiful? Since I came to visit from the country, I have not seen her close. Tell me, is she beautiful? 
[17]And her lips? 
[18]And her voice? Like lark song? 
[19]She sings too? 
[20]What of her bosom? 
[21]I think the lady is wise to keep your love at a distance. For what lady could live up to it close to, when her eyes and lips and voice may be no more beautiful than mine? Besides, can a lady born to wealth and noble marriage love happily with a Bankside poet and player? 
[22]But what of Lord Wessex? 
[23]
[24]Oh!--it's--it's--oh, it's a house of ill- repute! 
[25]The Admiral's Men! 
[26]My wick?
dialogues.QUEEN:
[1]Well played, Master Crab, I commend you. 
[2]Stand up straight, girl. 
[3]I have seen you. You are the one who comes to all the plays--at Whitehall, at Richmond. 
[4]What do you love so much? 
[5]Speak out! I know who I am. Do you love stories of kings and queens? Feats of arms? Or is it courtly love? 
[6]They are not acted for you, they are acted for me. 
[7]And--? 
[8]Above Lord Wessex? 
[9]My Lord--when you cannot find your wife you had better look for her at the playhouse. 
[10]But playwrights teach nothing about love, they make it pretty, they make it comical, or they make it lust. They cannot make it true. 
[11]I thought you were here because you had none. 
[12]Well, no one will take your wager, it seems. 
[13]Fifty pounds! A very worthy sum on a very worthy question. Can a play show us the very truth and nature of love? I bear witness to the wager, and will be the judge of it as occasion arises. I have not seen anything to settle it yet. So--the fireworks will be soothing after the excitements of Lady Viola's audience. Have her then, but you are a lordly fool. She has been plucked since I saw her last, and not by you. It takes a woman to know it. 
[14]Have a care with my name, you will wear it out. 
[15]The Queen of England does not attend exhibitions of public lewdness so something is out of joint. Come here, Master Kent. Let me look at you. 
[16]Yes, the illusion is remarkable and your error, Mr. Tilney, easily forgiven, but I know something of a woman in a man's profession, yes, by God, I do know about that. That is enough from you, Maser Kent. If only Lord Wessex were here. 
[17]There was a wager, I rememberas to whether a play can show the very truth and nature of love. I think you lost it today. You are an eager boy. Did you like the play? 
[18]Master Shakespeare. Next time to you come to Greenwich, Come as yourself and we will speak some more. WILL bows deeply. The QUEEN turns to leave. The waves part for her. 
[19]Why, Lord Wessex! Lost your wife so soon? 
[20]As stories must when love's denied--with tears and a journey. Those whom God has joined in marriage, not even I can put asunder. 
[21]Lord Wessex, as I foretold, has lost his wife in the play- house--go make your farewell and send her out. It's time to settle accounts. How much was the wager? 
[22]Give it to Master Kent. He will see it rightfully home. WESSEX gives his purse to VIOLA. 
[23]And tell Shakespeare something more cheerful next time for Twelfth Night. 
[24]Too late, too late.
dialogues.VIOLA AS ROMEO:
[1]"Is the day so young?" 
[2]"Ay me, sad hours seem long. Was that my father that went hence so fast?" 
[3]"Not having that which, having, makes them short." 
[4]"Out." 
[5]"Out of her favour where I am in love." 
[6]"Have not saints lips, and holy palmers too?" 
[7]"Oh then, dear saint, let lips do what hands to: They pray: grant thou, lest faith turn to despair." 
[8]"Then move not, while my prayer's effect I take." 
[9]"Thus from my lips, by thine, my sin is purg'd." 
[10]"Sin from my lips? Oh trespass sweetly urg'd. Give me my sin again." 
[11]Sin from my lips? Oh trespass sweetly urg'd. Give me my sin again." 
[12]"You kiss by th' book." 
[13]"What is her mother?" 
[14]"Is she a Capulet" Oh dear account. My life is my foe's debt." 
[15]"Ay, so I fear; the more is my unrest." 
[16]"The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars As daylight doth a lamp. Her eyes in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night. See how she leans her cheek upon her hand. O that I were a glove upon that hand, That I might touch that cheek. 
[17]"She speaks. 
[18]"Shall I hear more or shall I speak at this?" 
[19]"By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am: My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself Because it is an enemy to thee" 
[20]"Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye, Than twenty of their swords! Look thou but sweet, And I am proof against their enmity." 
[21]I have night's cloak to hide me from their eyes; And but thou love me, let them find me here. 
[22]"O wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?" 
[23]"The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine." 
[24]"Oh blessed blessed night."
dialogues.MARLOWE:
[1]How goes it, Will? 
[2]Burbage says you have a play. 
[3]Not new--my Doctor Faustus. 
[4]I have a new one nearly done, and better. The Massacre at Paris. 
[5]And yours? 
[6]What is the story? 
[7]Romeo isItalian. Always in and out of love. 
[8]Ethel. 
[9]The daughter of his enemy. 
[10]His best friend is killed in a duel by Ethel's brother or something. His name is Mercutio. 
[11]I thought your play was for Burbage. 
[12]A different one you haven't written? 
[13]Burbage! 
[14]Marlowe. 
[15]You are playing my Faustus this afternoon. Don't spend yourself in sport. 
[16]My Massacre at Paris is complete. 
[17]You have the money? 
[18]Then tomorrow you will have the pages. 
[19]Twenty pounds on delivery 
[20]Romeo?--he gave it to Henslowe. 
[21]Well, I am to Deptford now, I leave my respects, Miss Rosaline. 
[22]You did. But Ned Alleyn and the Admiral's Men have the playing of it as the Rose.
dialogues.TILNEY:
[1]She comes! 
[2]Like you, I found him not at home! 
[3]What does Burbage care of that? He is readying the Curtain for Kit Marlowe. 
[4]I have, Master Shakespeare. 
[5]Yes, I know. But he was always hanging around the house. 
[6]You will go far, I fear. 
[7]I hope we work together again. Tilney walks away. 
[8]My Lord Wessex! 
[9]Sedition and indecency! 
[10]Where, boy? 
[11]A woman on the stage? A woman? 
[12]So, Henslowe! I say this theatre is closed! On the authority of the powers invested in my by the court--I close this theatre! 
[13]For lewdness and unshamefacedness! For displaying a female on the public stage! 
[14]That's who I meant! This theatre is closed! Notice will be posted! 
[15]Closed! Closed, mark you, Henslowe! 
[16]I arrest you in the name of Queen Elizabeth! 
[17]Everybody! The Admiral's Men, The Chamberlain's Men and everyone of you ne'er-do-wells who stands in contempt of the authority invested in me by her Majesty. 
[18]That woman is a woman! 
[19]I'll see you all in the clink! In the same of her Majesty Queen Elizabeth
dialogues.SAM AS JULIET:
[1]"Ay pilgrim, lips that they must use in prayer." 
[2]"Saints do not move, though grant for prayer's sake." 
[3]"Then have my lips the sin that they have took." 
[4]"Come hither nurse. What is yond gentleman?" 
[5]"Go ask his name--If he be married, My grave is like to be my wedding bed." 
[6]"Ay me." 
[7]"Or if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love And I'll no longer be a Capulet." 
[8]I would not for the world! 
[9]"What satisfaction can'st thou have tonight?" 
[10]"I hear some noise within. Dear love, adieu." 
[11]"Anon, good Nurse--Sweet Montague be true." 
[12]"Stay but a little, I will come again." 
[13]"All my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay, And follow thee my lord throughout the world." 
[14]"I come, anon--But if thou meanest not well, I do beseech thee--" 
[15]By and by I come to cease thy strife and leave me to my grief. A thousand times good night!" 
[16]"Good night, good night. Parting is such sweet sorrow That I shall say good night till it be morrow."
dialogues.RALPH AS NURSE:
[1]"Madam, your mother craves a word with you." 
[2]"Marry bachelor, Her mother is the lady of the house" 
[3]"And a good lady, and wise and virtuous. I nurse her daughter that you talk'd withal" 
[4]"I tell you, he that can lay hold of her (he makes the money sign) Shall have the chinks." 
[5]"I know not." 
[6]"His name is Romeo, and a Montague, The only son of your great enemy." 
[7]"Madam!" 
[8]"Madam!" 
[9]"Now by my maidenhead at twelve year old, I bade her come. What, lamb. What ladybird." 
[10]"God forbid. Where's this girl? 
[11]"What, Juliet!" 
[12]"Your mother."
dialogues.BOATMAN:
[1]Right you are, governor! 
[2]I know your face. Are you an actor? 
[3]Yes, I've seen you in something. That one about a king. 
[4]I had the Christopher Marlowe in my boat once. 
[5]Sir Robert De Lesseps. 
[6]Writer, is he? 
[7]Thank you, my lady! 
[8]Viola De Lesseps. Known her since she was this high. Wouldn't deceive a child. 
[9]Strangely enough, I'm a bit of a writer myself. 
[10]It wouldn't take you long to read it, I expect you know all the booksellers . . .
dialogues.WILL AS ROMEO:
[1]Courage man. The hurt cannot be much. 
[2]"I am fortune's fool!" 
[3]"Farewell" 
[4]"Trust me, love, in my eyes so do you. Dry sorrow drinks our blood. Adieu. Adieu" 
[5]"Come hither, man. I see that thou art poor. Hold, there is forty ducats. Let me have A dram of poison--" 
[6]"I pay thy poverty and not thy will." 
[7]"Eyes, look your last! Arms, take your last embrace! and lips, Oh you The doors of breath, seal with a righteous kiss A dateless bargain to engrossing death! Come, bitter conduct; come, unsavory guide! Thou desparate pilot, now at once run on The dashing rocks thy seasick weary bark!" 
[8]"Here's to my love  O true Apothecary." 
[9]"Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kiss I die."
dialogues.SAM:
[1]I am, Master Shakespeare. 
[2]No, no, a touch of cold only. We suspect he is lying but WILL has turned away. 
[3]It's you. 
[4]I cannot move in this dress! and it makes me look like a pig! I have no neck in this pig dress! Oh, she's off again! She says she's going and then she doesn't 
[5]Iquite liked it. 
[6]Master Shakespeare 
[7]It is not my fault, Master Shakespeare. I could do it yesterday. 
[8]"Parting is such sweet sorrow"
dialogues.NOL AS BENVOLIO:
[1]"See where he comes. So please you step aside; I'll know his grievance or be much denied." 
[2]"Good morrow, cousin." 
[3]"But new struck nine." 
[4]It was. What sadness lengthens Romeo's hours?" 
[5]"In love?" 
[6]"Of love?" 
[7]"Away, be gone, the sport is at best." 
[8]"By my head, here comes the Capulets."
dialogues.VIOLA AS JULIET:
[1]"How now, who calls?" 
[2]"Madam. I am here, what is your will? 
[3]"Art thou gone so? 
[4]Love, lord, ay husband, friend, I must hear from thee every day in the hour, For in a minute there are many days. O, by this count I shall be much in years Ere I again behold my Romeo" 
[5]"O think'st thou we shall ever meet again? Methinks I see thee, now thou art so low, As one dead in the bottom of a tomb. Either my eyesight fails, or thou lookest pale." 
[6]"Where is my lord? 
[7]"What here? A cup clos'd in my true love's hand? Poison, I see, hath been his timeless end." 
[8]"O happy dagger
dialogues.WEBSTER:
[1]My lord! 
[2]Master of the Revels, sir, over here, sir. 
[3]I saw her bubbies! 
[4]I swear it! 
[5]Not him. her. 
[6]He did! I saw him kissing her bubbies! 
[7]I liked it when she stabbed herself, your Majesty.
dialogues.ROSALINE:
[1]When will you write me a sonnet, Will? 
[2]You left it in my bed. Come to look for it again. 
[3]Burbage has my keeping but you have my heart. 
[4]Will! 
[5]Willyou're the only one, Will!--in my heart. 
[6]This afternoon!--we'll still be here this afternoon.
dialogues.URCHIN:
[1]"the topless towers of Ilium? Sweet Helen, make me immortal with a--?" 
[2]I am Ethel, sir, the Pirate's daughter. 
[3]I was in a play. They cut my head off in Titus Andronicus. When I write plays, they will be like Titus. 
[4]I like it when they cut heads off. And the daughter mutilated with knives. 
[5]Plenty of blood. That is the only writing. 
[6]Wait, you'll see the cat bites his head off.
